stem: A 19-year-old client with a comminuted femur fracture is 24 hours post-injury. Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, two appropriate nursing actions, and two relevant parameters to monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: 14:00, A 19-year-old male presents with acute respiratory distress and neurological decline following a femur fracture.
Background: The client sustained a comminuted femur fracture 24 hours ago from a high-velocity motor vehicle accident. Skeletal traction was applied upon admission.
Assessment: The client is increasingly confused and agitated, described as 'combative.' Oxygen saturation has dropped to 84% despite administration of 4L of oxygen via nasal cannula. Fine, red petechial rash noted on chest and axillae. Vital Signs: BP 108/62, HR 122, RR 32, T 101.4°F.
Recommendation: STAT evaluation for Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES) including arterial blood gas analysis and chest X-ray.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: No medications administered at this time.

actionOptions.text: Administer high-flow oxygen via non-rebreather mask.
Ensure strict immobilization of the fractured extremity.
Instruct the client to perform leg exercises.

parameterOptions.text: Respiratory rate, SpO2, and lung sounds.
Neurological status and presence of petechiae.

rationale.correct: The client is exhibiting classic signs and symptoms of Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES) (c2), a serious complication that can occur following long-bone fractures. The hallmark triad includes respiratory distress (SpO2 84%), neurological decline (confusion, agitation), and a petechial rash. The 'snowstorm' infiltrates on the chest x-ray further support this diagnosis. Priority nursing actions include administering high-flow oxygen via a non-rebreather mask (a1) to address the hypoxemia and ensuring strict immobilization of the fractured extremity (a2) to minimize further embolization of fat globules. Monitoring should focus on continuous assessment of respiratory status, including respiratory rate, SpO2, and lung sounds (p1), as well as neurological status and the presence/progression of petechiae (p2).
clinicalPearls: FES typically occurs 24-72 hours post-fracture, but can occur up to a week later.
Treatment for FES is primarily supportive, focusing on oxygenation and hemodynamic stabilization.
The 'snowstorm' pattern on chest x-ray indicates acute lung injury due to the inflammatory response triggered by fatty acids in the pulmonary vasculature.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming this is a standard pulmonary embolism and selecting Heparin.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Heparin is used for blood clots, not fat emboli. The presence of a petechial rash in a patient with a recent long-bone fracture is a key indicator of FES. Furthermore, the chest x-ray findings are distinct from those typically seen in pulmonary embolism.

mnemonic.title: FES Triad
mnemonic.expansion: F - Fat in Lungs (Dyspnea, Hypoxia), E - Encephalopathy (Confusion, Agitation), S - Skin Spots (Petechiae)
